isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEHR POWER SYSTEMS/POWERLINE ALTERNATORS USED ON EMERGENCY VEHICLES - RATING CHARGING SYSTEMS / ALTERNATORS - CHARGING SYSTEM REQUIREMENT ADVISORY

para.emph: HEAVY DUTY CHARGING SYSTEM SELECTION GUIDELINES

entry.para: In many cases, the standard or production option charging system available from the Original Equipment Vehicle Manufacturer is electrically adequate for the broad range of applications and operating conditions anticipated.

The main benefit in having an adequately specified charging system is to help prolong battery life. Also, keeping batteries sufficiently charged provides good cranking motor performance and prolongs the motor's life expectancy. A stated goal of the industry is to improve the charging system durability and extend its life while simultaneously increasing or eliminating maintenance intervals.

More rapidly changing influences such as road speeds, engine speeds, fuel conservation, idle time, increased diesel engine use in light and medium duty vehicles, etc. may result in a vehicle with inadequate charging system capability, because operating conditions were not or could not be anticipated or prior experience was lacking.

The following guidelines to the fleet and commercial user are intended as an aid in establishing the requirements of the charging system for a given application and use. With the constantly increasing economic pressures, the fleet user may also desire to "custom tailor" to more specifically meet his needs, thus ensuring adequate system performance and durability while avoiding performance or weight excesses.

item.para: Charging line voltage drop between the alternator and battery should not exceed 1.0 volt at full output current for a 12-Volt system (Total of Both Positive and Negative Circuits).

Load dumping should be avoided. Master battery disconnect switches should not be opened with the engine running. Load dump protected alternators used on this vehicle design if such operation cannot be avoided. Newer alternators are designed for load dumps.

In the alternator output circuit, if a circuit breaker, fuse or other type of circuit protection is used, it should be rated at 150% current (ampere) capacity of the maximum cold alternator output rating.

seqlist.title: A Commonly used (50-10) method may be used for calculating capacity when current demand information is not available. This method produces a very conservative result which will usually provide a more than adequate charging system for most line haul operations.

item.para: Determine maximum continuous total electrical load, either by estimation from the Current Demand Chart or actual measurements on the vehicle.
Estimate or measure anticipated intermittent loads and multiply these by the expected usage percentage factor.
Add values determined in Steps A and B (Total Continuous Load).
Multiply the value obtained in Step 3 by 120%. This represents the total output requirement of the charging system.
Next, multiply the value obtained in Step 3 by 50%. This represents the output requirement at engine idle.

Determine or estimate the drive ratio of the charging system. The drive ratio is determined by measuring the diameter of the engine drive pulley and the alternator pulley and applying the following formula: ENGINE PULLEY DIAMETER / GENERATOR PULLEY DIAMETER = DRIVE RATIO

Multiply the drive ratio and the engine idle speed to determine the alternator's low-speed output. Then, compare the result to the alternator's performance curve to determine if the low-speed output requirement is met. DRIVE RATIO x IDLE SPEED = ALTERNATOR LOW SPEED

note.para: This procedure will not provide a "fine tuned" determination for special applications.

item.para: Determine the total load (continuous total load plus 20% of anticipated intermittent load). Total Load + (.20 X Intermittent Load ) = Total Continuous Load
Select a charging system with at least 20% greater maximum rated output. Total Load X 1.20 = Min. Alternator Output

note.para: In most cases, a 2.5:1 or better alternator drive ratio will provide a reasonably adequate system output.
